reasoning: The critique targets a moderately central plank: the essay’s use of de dicto motivation/WAM–AM categories (and “accurate convergence”) to frame prospects for partial convergence and bargaining, especially under antirealism. If de dicto motivation were incoherent or predictively empty under antirealism, that would weaken parts of sections 2–3, though it wouldn’t overturn the essay’s broader bottom-line (which is already pessimistic about WAM-convergence and emphasizes blockers/threats/power concentration). The critique’s key move—that under antirealism the choice of an ‘idealizer’ is just another preference, risking a collapse of de dicto into ‘de re toward my favored idealizer’—is partly right (there is a regress / free-parameter problem), but the essay substantially anticipates this in 2.4.2 by emphasizing subjective idealization and free parameters, and de dicto motivation can still be coherently defined agent-relatively (follow whatever reflective procedure one endorses) even if it doesn’t provide a shared attractor. Hence the critique weakens the explanatory/predictive usefulness more than it outright refutes a core claim. It is clearly written, focused on a single point, and contains little filler.
title: Antirealism collapses de dicto motivation into arbitrary idealizer choice
